snippet: Defenders of the native habitat of the Outer Banks of North Carolina fear that a recent increase in wild horses threatens the coastal ecosystem.
abstract: Advocates for horses and wildlife conservationists are squaring off over the fate of a herd of 140 wild horses on North Carolina's Outer Banks; herd, fenced into a 7,500 acre strip of land, faces a potential genetic collapse due to inbreeding; conservationists argue that the herd taxes the local ecosystem and should not be artificially maintained. Photos, Map (M)
lead_paragraph: COROLLA, N.C. -- Come summer, the beaches of this barrier island will be choked with cars and sunbathers, but in the off-season the land is left to wild horses. Smallish, tending toward chestnut and black, they wander past deserted vacation rentals in harems of five or six. Thousands of them once roamed the length of the Outer Banks of North Carolina, the likely descendants from mounts that belonged to Spanish explorers five centuries ago. Now their numbers have dwindled to a few hundred, the best known living on federal parkland at Shackleford Banks.

headline.main: Herd's Fate Lies in Preservation Clash
